questions.question_text: the following formats are appropriate for the web except...
questions.explanation: The Windows bitmap (BMP) format is an uncompressed format that will not be rendered by a web browser.

questions.question_text: true or false: an <img> element is a block-level element.
questions.explanation: It may come as a surprise, but the <img> tag is similar to <strong> and <emphasis>. Test this yourself by setting an image next to some text in a paragraph. The image will not occupy 100% of the width of the screen (or its parent element), as block-level elements do.

questions.question_text: <br>, <img>, and <meta> tags are all examples of...
questions.explanation: All of these tags don't have closing tags because they close themselves. What other tags don't have closing tags? Why not?

questions.question_text: the following statements about the GIF format are true except:

answers.answer_text: it does not support vector-based imagery

questions.explanation: The GIF format only supports 256 colors. Kinda crappy, right? Boo-ya!

questions.question_text: true or false: the larger the file size of imagery, the longer the page-load time.
questions.explanation: This is why the web uses “lossy” formats that compress imagery and squeeze out as much unnecessary information as possible.

questions.question_text: to make imagery accessible to the visually impaired, add the ______ attribute to the <img> tag.
questions.explanation: The “alt” attribute renders text in lieu of imagery to allow screenreader programs such as JAWS and NVDA to speak the text aloud. Our visually impaired friends need them, so please don't omit them. Learn more about web content accessibility guidelines.

questions.question_text: a 5 megabyte image with an image tag like <img width="100" height="100"> will load...

answers.answer_text: as quickly as if it were resized to 100px by 100px
one-fifth as quickly as if it were resized to 100px by 100px
as long as a 5 megabyte file takes to load
one hundred times faster than with its original dimensions

questions.explanation: This question does not require mathematical reasoning. Resizing an image in an image editor changes a file's size on disk. Setting the width and height attributes on a webpage only changes the size at which the image appears in the browser. A 5MB image will take the same amount of time to load regardless of the width and height attributes. Therefore, always properly resize imagery!

questions.question_text: the GIF format was created by which internet service provider?
questions.explanation: The GIF format was patented by CompuServe in 1987. According to Wikipedia (where Everything Is True Because It Is In Writing), a licensing dispute prompted the development of the PNG format, which was made freely available for use.

questions.question_text: one of the earliest and most famous animated GIFs is...

answers.answer_text: a cat surfing on a roomba
a bird pooping on another bird

questions.explanation: As we all know, babies and animals (especially cats) rule the web. But the Oogachacka Baby got there first in the late 1990s.
